Award.AwardTitle: Enhancing Participation Research Project: Minority Status and Stereotypes: The Benefits and Consequences as they Relate to STEM Participation and Success at an HBCU

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Howard University requests support for an HBCU-UP Broadening Participation Research in STEM education project entitled Minority Status and Stereotypes: The Benefits and Consequences as they relate to STEM Participation and Success at an HBCU. The proposed project will employ a mixed-methods research design to examine within-group ethnic differences between domestic and international black STEM undergraduates relative to academic achievement. It will investigate factors that impact the academic experiences of these students. Specifically, the study will apply cultural ecology theory and identity theory to understand within-group distinctions; explore minority status, stereotypes, and stereotyped expectations, and academic and ethnic identity among black STEM students; and examine students familiarity with experiences characterized by the model minority stereotype in conjunction with their participation and success in STEM.

The proposed research can potentially advance the knowledge about how to better prepare faculty to teach in multi-cultural environments. The results can be used also to mitigate stereotyping of both domestic and international black students and has implications for multiple disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The presence of international students on U.S. college campuses has been reported to have both a positive and negative effect on U.S. domestic students. This study examined the impact of the presence of Black international students on an HBCU campus where the student population is predominantly African American.  We focused on STEM majors as we examined the experiences of Black domestic and Black international undergraduates to better understand the dynamics of their co-existent academic life at an HBCU.

Our data shows that Black international students and Black domestic students have different challenges while majoring in STEM disciplines. Both groups of students must contend with stereotypes. International Black students are perceived as more intelligent than domestic Black students. Domestic Black students noted the difficulties experienced in combating low academic expectations by others. In both cases, stereotypes were seen to be damaging and limiting. We found that often times when Black international students failed to meet the high academic standards expected in STEM disciplines, these students were more prone to abandon STEM and study disciplines where awareness of such stereotypes may be less pronounced. For Black domestic students, the constant need to combat negative stereotypes has often led to a phenomenon known as ‘racial battle fatigue’. Like their international counterparts, we risk losing these students in STEM disciplines.

It is imperative that the U.S focuses it efforts on tapping into the potential of all its citizens to address the shortage of a highly educated and technically trained STEM workforce. STEM professionals are needed to protect our borders, enhance our cyber security and maintain strong international leadership. These efforts require domestic engineers who are able to obtain the necessary security clearances for these responsible positions. 

Interestingly, there are a number of publications that report the increasing numbers of minorities entering the STEM professions. These data can be misleading.  For example, most published data sets group all Blacks together as a monolithic group regardless of their international or domestic status. The data should be disaggregated to more accurately reflect the situation for Black domestic STEM professionals.  Furthermore, the numbers alone do not allow for a full understanding of the experiences of Black STEM professional and students, both domestic and international. The results of this study contribute to the understanding of the experiences and challenges of both groups of Black students.
